summary.abstract: This chapter surveys the development of Islamicate geography and cartography from the origins of Arabic geographical writing through the major achievements of the 7th/13th century. Beginning with translations from Indian, Persian, and Greek sources, the tradition established two dominant modes: mathematical geography following Ptolemy's model and administrative geography focused on routes and routes and itineraries. The 'Balkhī School' of the 4th/10th century integrated maps with regional text to produce distinctive atlases of the Islamic world, while al-Bīrūnī's mathematical advances and al-Idrīsī's synthesis at the Norman Sicilian court represent high points of the tradition. The chapter also discusses subgenres including cosmographical literature, encyclopedias of place-names, and travel writing.
